noun.description: A mass of small bubbles in liquid caused by agitation, fermentation, etc.; foam.
examples: leave the yeast until there is a good head of froth

noun.description: Worthless or insubstantial talk, ideas, or activities.

verb.description: Form or contain a rising or overflowing mass of small bubbles.
examples: he took a quick sip of beer as it frothed out of the can
scooping salmon out of the frothing gorge

phrases: By the time he arrived, several more hours later, I was beginning to froth at the mouth.
I was screaming, cussing, frothing at the mouth.
His eyes rolled frighteningly, he frothed at the mouth.
Oddly, I felt more dressed-down by his gracious reply than I'd have been had he frothed at the mouth.
I realize everyone else is frothing at the mouth about Iran.
origin: Late Middle English: from Old Norse frotha, frauth.
